Comment: with the goal of getting to d4. 16...Bf2 was the other option. The dark-squared bishop is needed to help the passed e-pawn go further up the board. White king is now in a very precarious position.
It is normally quite bad to move a piece twice in the opening, especially the Queen. The castling aids development and protects the g7-pawn under threat.

Continues the pressure on White queen. Also threatens the White Bishop on c4, and protects the Black Knight on e4.

Originally planning 11...Ng5 or 11...Nf6 I felt 11...Bf5 was better as it brought a piece into the action, connected the rooks and protects the vulnerable knight on e4.

I don't understand why White wasn't aiming to bring the bishop and knight into action. Anyway, I ignored that and brought out a rook to threaten the bishop and gain control of the d-file. My development is nearly complete. Because I'm currently up in material, I am going to aim for a knight sacrifice on d4 to bring the e-pawn onto the d-file so that it is supported by the rook, and then eventually get rid of the d-pawn by moving the bishop to g5.

threatens the knight and frees up the d2-h6 diagonal for the bishop.

A nice escape square which continues the pressure and opens the way for my light-squared bishop. Anticipating c4 which will open up the way for the as-yet undeveloped knight and protect the isolated bishop on d5, I will then check the king with the bishop before removing the knight before it can take part in the action.
And this time the predict-a-move ploy works!
Aaaaargh the temptation the temptation. If I still can't think of anything else at the end of the day. I will take the knight, but otherwise I must find the best way to keep the king in check.
